Reaching ambitious mitigation targets will likely lead to higher energy prices and a greater demand for bioenergyâ€”at least in the medium term (
27 ). These two factors would further reinforce the impacts of SWS on wheat prices, such as the recently observed price peaks. Decoupling future production-side shocks from price spikes will thus require coordinated efforts in stock management to maintain the stock-to-use ratio at safe levels and the control of financial markets to minimize the price reaction beyond the fundamental drivers. Last, liberalized trade has often been advocated as a potentially efficient adaptation measure (
28 ,
29 ), while unilateral restrictive trade policies contribute to aggravating recent price spikes. A solid framework for the global coordination of trade policies will thus be necessary to allow trade to alleviate rather than exacerbate the effects of regional extremes on global markets.
